availability.p: Copyright Records of Early English Drama (REED), 2024
availability.licence: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0) licence.

sourceDesc.p: Born digital. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

div.head: How REED Defines Locations
div.p: This list of locations and definitions was

row.cell: A level area in which sports, entertainments, and other public events are held. Includes cockpits, tiltyards, animal baiting arenas.

Bear Garden 3,
Tiltyard at Whitehall
New Oxford American Dictionary, 3rd ed. Amended.

A structure forming or carrying a road, path, etc., which spans a body of water, a roadway, a valley, or some other obstacle or gap, and allows a person or vehicle to pass unimpeded over or across it.
London Bridge
OED 1. Amended.

A building for public Christian worship or rites such as baptism, marriage, etc., traditionally cruciform in shape, and typically having a tower, dome, or spire; distinguished originally from an oratory or place of private prayer.
Westminster Abbey; Christ Church Newgate Street, church of; St Martin Ludgate, church of
OED 1a.

A house owned by a church; esp. a building next to a church, in which social events, meetings, etc., connected with the church are held; a church hall. Also: a house provided by the church for a member of the clergy; a parochial
OED
The territory of a nation
England, France, Ireland, Scotland
OED 5. Amended.
An administrative division of England, Scotland, Wales, and Ireland
Surrey, Sussex, Middlesex
OED I.
A geographic region formally connected to a religious organization, such as a diocese, archdeaconry, etc. Does not include parishes.
Diocese of Winchester, Archdeaconry of Surrey

An opening in a wall, made for the purpose of entrance and exit, and capable of being closed by a movable barrier, the existence of which is usually implied; said with reference to a city or other enclosure, or the enclosure-wall of a large building, formerly also to the building itself, where door or doors is now commonly employed.
Aldgate, Bishopsgate, Cripplegate
OED 1.
The hall in which a guild met. From its use as a meeting-place for the town and corporation often synonymous with ‘town-hall’
Bakers' Hall, Merchant Taylors' Hall
OED

A house or hostel for the reception and entertainment of pilgrims, travellers, and strangers; a hospice. Hence, one of the establishments of the Knights Hospitallers. or an institution or establishment for the care of the sick or wounded, or of those who require medical treatment.
Bethlehem Hopsital
OED 1 and 3.

The four sets of buildings in London (the Inner Temple, the Middle Temple, Lincoln's Inn, and Gray's Inn) belonging to the four legal societies which have the exclusive right of admitting persons to practise at the bar, and hold a course of instruction and examination for that purpose; hence, these four societies themselves.
Inner Temple, Middle Temple, Lincoln's Inn, Gray's Inn
OED 5c.

(a) An area of local administration distinct from neighbouring territory and possessing a degree of independence. In extended use: a precinct, a domain. Also in plural in same sense. (b) The district outside a city over which its jurisdiction extends. Also in plural in same sense. (c) Chiefly in plural and also with capital initial. An area outside a prison within which, on payment of a security, certain prisoners, esp. debtors, were permitted to reside.
Clink, St Bartholomew's Hospital, Tower of London
OED 6c.

An estate of a lord, including both the land and the manor house or mansion; a landed possession. Note: Manor houses themselves are categorized as "residences" and may have different names from the manor itself. If the name is the same, then the manor house name is capitalized (eg, Holcombe Burnell Manor)
Paris Garden manor
OED 1. Emphasis and note added.
An open space, often with poorly defined boundaries, such as a field, park, forest, market, etc
Finsbury Fields, Lambeth Marsh, Lincoln's Inn Fields, Smithfield Market, Covent Garden
OED "area" 1.
catch all for misfits; misc.
sewers

An area or district having its own priest, vicar, or other incumbent under the jurisdiction of a bishop (to whom tithes and ecclesiastical dues were formally paid); a territorial subdivision of a diocese. The smallest unit of local government in many rural areas.The existing ecclesiastical parishes were adopted by the Tudor state for civil purposes in a series of legislative measures beginning in the 1530s. These involved the parish having local responsibility for vital registration, highways, militia matters, and, above all, poor relief, roles which were largely retained until the 1830s.
St Saviour Southwark, All Hollows Bread Street, St Margaret Fish Street
OED 2a. and 3a. Amended.
A building or other location where people are disciplined for a crime or other offence, where people are held while awaiting trial, or where people are incarcerated.
Marshalsea Prison, Newgate prison, Tower Hill, Tyburn, Poultry Compter
OED "prison" 1b. Significantly amended.
An edifice specially adapted to dramatic representations
Rose Playhouse, Fortune Playhouse, Theatre playhouse
OED "theatre" 2a.
A piece of land under one ownership. Sometimes a landed estate.
Little Rose property, the Unicorn
OED 3c. Slightly amended.
A house or building inhabited by a religious order; an abbey, monastery, convent, etc.; places where the religious orders lived and includes: priories, friaries, monasteries, nunneries, etc.
Charterhouse, Holywell Priory
OED. amended
The place where a person resides; the dwelling place or home of a person (esp. one of some rank or distinction).
Hampton Court, Tower of London, St. James' Palace, Bishop of Winchester's palace
OED 4a.
An establishment or institution for the formal education of children or young people. Includes colleges and universities as well as grammar schools, primary schools etc.
Westminster Grammar School, Eton, Trinity College Cambridge, St Paul's School
OED II. 5a. Amended.
A collection of dwelling-houses and other buildings identified as a single geo-political or administrative unit (such as a town or city).
OED "village" 1a. and TEI def of settlement. Amended.
A path or way between different places, or leading to some place (including lanes, alleys, roads)
Fleet Street, Rose Alley, Watling Street
OED "road" 4a.

A building used for the administration of local government, the holding of court sessions, public meetings, entertainments, etc.; (in early use also) a large hall used for such purposes within a larger building or set of buildings.
OED 1a.
A house where victuals are supplied or sold; an eating-house, inn, or tavern
Bell and Cock Inn, Boar's Head Inn
OED.

An administrative division of a borough or city; originally, a district under the jurisdiction of an alderman. Also, the people of such a district collectively.In Anglo-Latin documents the wards (wardæ) of London are mentioned by that name from the 12th cent., sometimes designated by the name of the alderman and sometimes by their locality.
OED 19a.
A body or mass of standing or flowing water (natural or artificial), irrespective of size or type; a sea, lake, river, etc.
River Thames, Great Conduit, Skinner's Well
OED "water" 11a. Amended.
